profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Monday March 25, 2019 at 22:54

did.abstract: Correspondence, writings, and collected material document the life and work of Eugene A. Turner, who served under the YMCA in China from 1913 to 1947. Turner was involved in student and city work for the Y.M.C.A. in China and was a keen observer of Chinese customs and political events.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Copyright has not been transferred to Yale University

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Eugene A. Turner Papers (RG 206), Special Collections, Yale Divinity School Library.

list.item: II. Writings and Notes, 1913-1948, no date
III. Personal Items and Memorabilia, 1929-1943, no date

bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: Eugene A. Turner was born in Wake Forest, North Carolina. He had completed a Bachelor's Degree, Master's Degree, and Law Degree at Wake Forest College by 1906. After a year of teaching at a preparatory school, Turner became Y.M.C.A. Secretary at the Georgia School of Technology. In 1913 Turner went to China under the Y.M.C.A. and worked with students in the city of Hangchow. According to a biographical sketch, Turner "built up a Y.M.C.A. which, in a short time, enlisted the support of government officials and the literati. He also helped to train an efficient staff of Chinese to whom he relinquished the executive work, remaining as an advisor. He organized, coached and conducted the first inter-scholastic football league ever attempted in Hangchow. Other activities were pioneered: debates, oratorical contests, essay contests, etc. He organized Bible study groups among the students." After a furlough, Turner returned to China in 1928 and was sent to Wuchang and served as Y.M.C.A. General Secretary. He later served in Nanchang, home of the New Life Movement and had personal contact with General and Madame Chiang Kai-shek. Turner was a leader in the Christian Rehabilitation Center in Kiangsi Province, which was involved in the rehabilitation of districts previously held by Communist forces. Turner was married to Mary Effie Lee Turner and was the father of Frank Turner and Eugene Alfred Turner, Jr., who was also involved in Y.M.C.A. work.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Eugene A. Turner Papers complement other collections of China Y.M.CA. workers held at the Divinity School Library, including the papers of Lyman Hoover, Dwight W.Edwards, Lennig Sweet, and Austin Long, as well as China Y.M.C.A. records in the archives of the World Student Christian Federation.

The majority of the family correspondence is from the war years when Eugene Turner was separated from his wife and children. General correspondence includes letters to and from Madame Chiang Kai-shek, as well as Y.M.C.A. colleagues. The reports from China in Series II are excellent substantive reports of Turner's work with the Y.M.C.A. dating from 1913 to 1947. He also comments on political events and describes Chinese customs. The documentation of these reports is supplemented by writings in Series III.

did.unittitle: With Armed Forces: China, Burma, India
With Armed Forces: China, Burma, India
With Armed Forces: China, Burma, India
From Hangchung-Chengtu-Kunming, Calcutta- Sons in US, Mrs. Tryon, NC
From Eugene Jr.-Marine Corps. Chaplin- China
From Tryon, NC-, Eugene Turner, Jr. China, NJ
Letters of Eugene Turner to/from others
To/from Mary Connally, several from Frank Lenz, Educational Secretary of the YMCA
From Herschleb, Barnett, to Chairman and Madame Chiang Kai-Shek
Some re. stamp collecting, Hugh Hubbard
From Jay Oliver- incl. letter of Eugene, Jr to Oliver also
Includes description of fall of Nanking by George Fitch
EAT reports from Hangchow, including description of life in city, address by Governor at opening of Y.M.C.A, Sherwood Eddy campaign (1914), athletic and educational work, political unrest
EAT reports from Hangchow and Shanghai, including re. Y.M.C.A. membership campaign, travels throughout China, patriotic demonstrations
EAT reports from Hangchow, including re. World Student Christian Federation meeting in Peking, political unrest, campaign of popular education,

EAT reports from Hangchow and Wuchang, including re. Chinese customs, burning of the kitchen god, Y.M.C.A. membership campaign, "popular education in the meaning of citizenship"; move from student work to city work
EAT reports from Wuchang, including re. membership campaign, Feng Yu-shiang the Christian General, civil war, visit of Dr. Kirby Page

EAT reports from Wuchang, Kuling, Tryon NC, including regarding flood relief, Japanese troops, return home due to Y.M.C.A. financial situation, engagement as teacher of English Literature at Central China College, Wuchang, return to Y.M.C.A. work, New Life Movement; appointment as Regional Secretary for Shantung
EAT reports from Tsingtao, Hankow, and elsewhere in China; war rehabilitation work, retirement
Annual reports of EAT from Hangchow and Shanghai
Articles by EAT, including "Injecting leaven into the lump"
Articles by EAD, including regarding Japanese occupation of Hangchow, "Some reasons for disturbed conditions in China," "Life sketch of Wen Shih-Tsen"
Notes of EAD: textiles in China, for talks, sermons
Writings of others: "Report on China situation," "The Bible marches on," "A new variety of 1905", report on work of Euguene A. Turner, Jr. for Home Missions Council of North America
Regarding Y.M.C.A.: broadcasts, newsletters, report letters of S.C. Leung, Lyman Hoover
Biographical sketch, photographs, passports and health certificate, financial records, tribute

Booklets, articles including "An Outline of the Organization of the Kuomintang and the Chinese Government", "Bulltown" newspaper for American troops in China and India, "A Letter from Madame Chiang Kai-shek to Boys and Girls Across the Ocean"
Typescript copy of journal of Elisha Loomis, who was among the first company of missionaries to Hawaii; journal documents Loomis's tour of Hawaii in 1824-1826
"Shanghai's Schemozzle" (reprinted cartoons and "In Parenthesis" observations from North China Daily News)
